I can't tell if you have activate the necessary Conda environment or not. But this usually occurs when one forgets to:
mamba activate moose
before running make.
This is a little weird though:
/bin/sh: line 0: [: -ne: unary operator expected

Not sure where that's coming from.

Thanks Jason that helped solve the issue, but now I am running into these errors:

It looks like there was an update involved (you updated the moose repo, or you updated Conda). When one occurs, so must the other. I am not sure which was done, so we will do them both:
mamba activate moose
cd ~/projects/moose
git pull
mamba update --all
Then, it is necessary to clean up any stale/old build files lying around in the moose repo:
git clean -xfd
Note: this will delete any untracked files. So if you are making changes to moose, be sure to save those changes before running git clean.
Once this is all complete, you should be able to run make again.

scripts/versioner.py libmesh --yaml | grep install
mamba list | grep moose

Well there is something wrong with or how mamba is being initialized. Due to the strange operator error that bash is mentioning, it might be due to something at odds in your ~/.bash_profile.
I am guessing you have the initialization routines at the top of the ~/.bash_profile, and later on, something is messing around with paths variables which are affecting Mamba somehow...
Can you show us your bash profile? Might be able to help:
cat ~/.bash_profile

Ah I see. Okay, here it is:
# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!
__conda_setup="$('/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin/conda' 'shell.bash' 'hook' 2> /dev/null)"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    eval "$__conda_setup"
else
    if [ -f "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh" ]; then
        . "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh"
    else
        export PATH="/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup

if [ -f "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh" ]; then
    . "/Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/mamba.sh"
fi
# <<< conda initialize <<<

export = PATH=$PATH:$HOME/projects/moose/python/peacock/

While that may solve the operator error... I think that that PATH= line would not break Mamba...
You might need to reinstall Mamba. If you've only been using Conda for MOOSE based stuff, it should be safe to delete, and re-install...
rm -rf /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Apple Silicon Mac:
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Mambaforge-MacOSX-arm64.sh
sh Mambaforge-MacOSX-arm64.sh -b -p /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Intel Mac:
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Mambaforge-MacOSX-x86_64.sh
sh Mambaforge-MacOSX-x86_64.sh -b -p /Users/nabzforcemac/mambaforge3


Exit your terminal, and re-open it... see if you can run mamba commands without those errors:
mamba list
If the above works without those crazy errors, you'll need to re-create the 'moose' environment:
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
mamba activate moose
and hopefully, you should be able to build once more.

node.title: Make a csv file from a class that derives from “Material”
node.bodyText:
I am writing a class that derives from “Material.”
My program includes such as:
.
_length(declareProperty<Real>("length")),
_temperature(coupledValue("heat_variable"))
.

float some_constant = 100;
_length[_qp] = some_constant * _temperature[_qp];

Now, I would like to generate a csv file includes member variable “_length[_qp].”
Please help.
S. Thomas

hello
Just set the output_properties and outputs parameter in the input for this Material.
Or do you want "output" to always be done?
[Materials]
[ my _mat ]
   ...
   output_properties= 'length'
    outputs = 'csv'
  []
[Outputs]
  [csv]
    type = CSV
  []
[]

Thank you GiudGiudty,
Are you suggesting to use "type = OutputTestMaterial?"
Yes, I would like it done always.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas

no the type is the type of your Material.
Always might be difficult actually, because the csv output block might not exist.
You could set the default of outputs to 'all' ?

For a quick check, I am using the below.
It did not make a csv file but the 'diff_u' is included in the exodus file.
A csv file is supposed to be generated, isn't it?
Please help.
[Materials]
  [./conduct_u]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'diff_u'
    prop_values = 1.0
    block = 0
    output_properties = 'diff_u'
    outputs = 'csv'
  [../]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  [csv]
    type = CSV
  []
[]

I remember that the Elemental variable family is not shown in a csv file. So, 'diff_u' may have the Elemental variable family. I will work on my "_length[_qp]" to see if I can print it in a csv file.
Sincerely,
S. Thomas

oh  somehow I did not connect that this CSV output wasnt going to get set up automatically.
This wont work. Let me find a different solution

This is the object you want to use
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/MaterialVectorPostprocessor.html

Thank you, Guillaume!
Actually I would like to make a CSV file for values along boundary lines. In that case, do you recommend to use "LineValueSampler" or any other methods like giving the boundary numbers (or names) instead of coordinates.  Please help. S. Thomas

If the boundaries are straight lines, then LineValueSampler is the one to go with.
If not, then we do not have a BoundaryValueSampler.
However, if you are OK with the odd workflow you could:

use LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator on the boundary of interest
use the ElementValueSampler and block restrict it to that lower D block

node.title: PhD and postdoctoral openings
node.bodyText:
The Clean Energy and Water (CEW) lab at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) has openings for one Ph.D. student (Spring 2023) and one postdoc fellow starting as early as possible. Candidates with a background in computational mechanics/materials/electrochemistry are encouraged to apply.
We are doing research on Li-ion batteries, with a focus on the fundamental understanding of the transport effects with the coupling of mechanics, electrochemistry, and materials. Skills with continuum modeling (finite element and phase field), multi-physics modeling, or multi-scale modeling are preferred.
We seek motivated and dynamic colleagues to join our culturally diverse research team, more broadly, at RIT. It is a super active lab in the Department of Mechanical Engineering and Chemical Engineering. You will get hands-on support from the advisor, and grow fast with all the young people in the lab. Please refer to the CEW website for more information: http://www.cewlab.org/
Please send a cover letter and your personal curriculum vitae to Professor Howard Tu: howard.tu@rit.edu

BASH_FUNC__module_raw%%=() {  unset _mlshdbg;
 if [ "${MODULES_SILENT_SHELL_DEBUG:-0}" = '1' ]; then
 case "$-" in 
 *v*x*)
 set +vx;
 _mlshdbg='vx'
 ;;
 *v*)
 set +v;
 _mlshdbg='v'
 ;;
 *x*)
 set +x;
 _mlshdbg='x'
 ;;
 *)
 _mlshdbg=''
 ;;
 esac;
 fi;
 unset _mlre _mlIFS;
 if [ -n "${IFS+x}" ]; then
 _mlIFS=$IFS;
 fi;
 IFS=' ';
 for _mlv in ${MODULES_RUN_QUARANTINE:-};
 do
 if [ "${_mlv}" = "${_mlv##*[!A-Za-z0-9_]}" -a "${_mlv}" = "${_mlv#[0-9]}" ]; then
 if [ -n "`eval 'echo ${'$_mlv'+x}'`" ]; then
 _mlre="${_mlre:-}${_mlv}_modquar='`eval 'echo ${'$_mlv'}'`' ";
 fi;
 _mlrv="MODULES_RUNENV_${_mlv}";
 _mlre="${_mlre:-}${_mlv}='`eval 'echo ${'$_mlrv':-}'`' ";
 fi;
 done;
 if [ -n "${_mlre:-}" ]; then
 eval `eval ${_mlre} /usr/bin/tclsh /cineca/prod/opt/environment/module/4.7.0/none/libexec/modulecmd.tcl bash '"$@"'`;
 else
 eval `/usr/bin/tclsh /cineca/prod/opt/environment/module/4.7.0/none/libexec/modulecmd.tcl bash "$@"`;
 fi;
 _mlstatus=$?;
 if [ -n "${_mlIFS+x}" ]; then
 IFS=$_mlIFS;
 else
 unset IFS;
 fi;
 unset _mlre _mlv _mlrv _mlIFS;
 if [ -n "${_mlshdbg:-}" ]; then
 set -$_mlshdbg;
 fi;
 unset _mlshdbg;
 return $_mlstatus
}

}

BASH_FUNC__module_raw%%=() {  unset _mlshdbg;
 if [ "${MODULES_SILENT_SHELL_DEBUG:-0}" = '1' ]; then
 case "$-" in 
 *v*x*)
 set +vx;
 _mlshdbg='vx'
 ;;
 *v*)
 set +v;
 _mlshdbg='v'
 ;;
 *x*)
 set +x;
 _mlshdbg='x'
 ;;
 *)
 _mlshdbg=''
 ;;
 esac;
 fi;
 unset _mlre _mlIFS;
 if [ -n "${IFS+x}" ]; then
 _mlIFS=$IFS;
 fi;
 IFS=' ';
 for _mlv in ${MODULES_RUN_QUARANTINE:-};
 do
 if [ "${_mlv}" = "${_mlv##*[!A-Za-z0-9_]}" -a "${_mlv}" = "${_mlv#[0-9]}" ]; then
 if [ -n "`eval 'echo ${'$_mlv'+x}'`" ]; then
 _mlre="${_mlre:-}${_mlv}_modquar='`eval 'echo ${'$_mlv'}'`' ";
 fi;
 _mlrv="MODULES_RUNENV_${_mlv}";
 _mlre="${_mlre:-}${_mlv}='`eval 'echo ${'$_mlrv':-}'`' ";
 fi;
 done;
 if [ -n "${_mlre:-}" ]; then
 eval `eval ${_mlre} /usr/bin/tclsh /cineca/prod/opt/environment/module/4.7.0/none/libexec/modulecmd.tcl bash '"$@"'`;
 else
 eval `/usr/bin/tclsh /cineca/prod/opt/environment/module/4.7.0/none/libexec/modulecmd.tcl bash "$@"`;
 fi;
 _mlstatus=$?;
 if [ -n "${_mlIFS+x}" ]; then
 IFS=$_mlIFS;
 else
 unset IFS;
 fi;
 unset _mlre _mlv _mlrv _mlIFS;
 if [ -n "${_mlshdbg:-}" ]; then
 set -$_mlshdbg;
 fi;
 unset _mlshdbg;
 return $_mlstatus
}
BASH_FUNC_ml%%=() {  module ml "$@"
}

node.title: Switch from DirichletBC to NeumannBC
node.bodyText:
All,
My model starts with a Dirichlet boundary condition with a zero value but when the flux value reaches a specified value
I would like to switch a Dirichlet boundary to a Neumann boundary condition with a flux value calculated in a Material object.
I know "TimePeriod" in [Control] is available but I have not found a way to activate the boundary condition switch by a parameter available in my model.
Please help. S. Thomas

Hello
Control is the way to go.
What error are you getting?
Guillaume

Thank you, Guillaume.
I have not figured it out yet. I can make a switch by specifying a time using "TimePeriod" but I would like to do the switch when the flux value reaches a specified value calculated in a Material object. I still don't know how to do that.
S. Thomas

Use this one instead of TimePeriod:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/ConditionalFunctionEnableControl.html
the function can depend on postprocessors (ParsedFunction) and the PP can look a the flux

Guillaume,
I looked at the examples in the link. They are hard to understand.  Do you have friendlier ones?
Please help. S. Thomas

can you paste your BCs block here?
and how do you compute the criterion for the switch? is it in your postprocessors already?
I ll write the control for you

Control.zip
Guillaume,
It would be appreciated if you could take a look at what I am trying to do.
In the attached files, FluxMaterial starts to calculate the flux with zero DirichletBC. The maximum flux is specified to be 150 and once the flux reaches 150, flux of 150 is set in MaterialNeumannBC. The challenge is how to switch from DirichletBC to MaterialNeumannBC for variable "u" in Block 0. I am using "TimePeriod" here but it is not accurate. Please help. I would like to thank you for your time and consideration.

Try something like:
[Postprocessors]
    [max_flux]
    type = ElementExtremeMaterialProperty
    mat_prop = "flux_value"
    value_type = max
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [conditional_function]
    type = ParsedFunction'
    expression = 'if(max_flux > 150, 1, 0)'
    symbol_names = max_flux
    symbol_values = max_flux
  []
[]

[Controls]
    [switch_up]
    type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
    enable_objects = 'BCs::u_interface01_Dirichlet'
    disable_objects = 'BCs::u_interface01_Neumann'
    conditional_function = 'conditional_function'
  []
[]

node.title: Radiative Heat Flux as a Kernel

node.bodyText:
I don't think the math works out like that. You are basically approximating a boundary integral (the original radiation BC) with a volume integral (using the switch function). Typically, people in the phase field community use an indicator function to do the regularization. See section 2.1 of "A phase-field model of quasi-brittle fracture for pressurized cracks: Application to UO
high-burnup microstructure fragmentation". The derivation tells you how to do the approximation with gamma convergence.
Okay that would explain our results, I'll take a look at that paper. Thanks for your help

Hi @hugary1995 , I have had a look through the paper you recommended, thank you for that. I can't seem to understand how this would be implemented into MOOSE at the minute.
Would you be able to explain any further, as I think this paper is currently slightly beyond my understanding.
If I share my current kernel would you be able to explain the implementation please?
All the best,
Lloyd

I wrote down some equations to explain.
scratch_paper.pdf
Eq. 4 is what you need to implement. OP was only missing that indicator function. Though you do need to figure out how to construct/solve/update the order parameter. If you have a level-set, that would simplify things.
I suspect MALAMUTE already has something like this. @jiangwen84 would know.

Thank you very much.
I have found the relevant MALAMUTE code now also: https://github.com/idaholab/malamute/blob/devel/src/kernels/MeltPoolHeatSource.C
I think the only step I am missing now is now to implement the Indicator function/ level set.
In eq4 is it the indicator function or the magnitude of the gradient of the indicator function that you integrate over?
Thanks again,
Lloyd
oops, that was a typo. It should be magnitude of the gradient of the indicator function.
Thank you very much for your help, I have made a working solution now based on your explanation.
Fantastic!

node.title: Constructor of Materials systems
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am going through the "darcy_thermo_mech(step03)" app from the MOOSE training material.  I am trying to understand the constructor and destructor of PackedColumn class.
It looks like the constructor of PackedColumn is called 3 times even if the simulation is performed serially (i.e. no threads, no MPI). 1)Why is the constructor called 3 times ? Usually, we expect the constructor should be called only once right ?
2)Also, where should I specify the destructor ? Should I have to override any routines ? Will the destructor be also called multiple times ?
I added the "cout" statement in the constructor as shown below:
PackedColumn::PackedColumn(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : Material(parameters),

    // Get the parameters from the input file
    _radius(getFunction("radius")),
    _input_viscosity(getParam<Real>("viscosity")),

    // Declare two material properties by getting a reference from the MOOSE Material system
    _permeability(declareADProperty<Real>("permeability")),
    _viscosity(declareADProperty<Real>("viscosity"))
{
  // From the paper: Table 1
  std::vector<Real> sphere_sizes = {1, 3};
  std::vector<Real> permeability = {0.8451e-9, 8.968e-9};
  // Set the x,y data on the LinearInterpolation object.
  _permeability_interpolation.setData(sphere_sizes, permeability);

/*
 *Print statement to check how many times materials constructor is called.
 */
  std::cout<<"INFO: Called PackedColumn constructor "<<std::endl; 
}

As you can see above, INFO: Called PackedColumn constructor line is printed 3 times in the output.

1)Why is the constructor called 3 times ? Usually, we expect the constructor should be called only once right ?

Constructor is called 3 times for the element, face and neighbor copies of the material properties most likely.
You dont need to specify the destructor unless you are performing manual memory management. The desctructor for the base class and the interfaces you inherit should do all the work for you
For the deprecation warning, we re fixing that before the MOOSE training Tuesday

One more thing, when I did similar test with AuxKernel (DarcyVelocity), I observed that is called only once. Wont Auxkernel also need element, face and neighbour copies ?

No there's only one auxkernel. It will be replicated per process though.
The thing is, there s no need for storage for auxkernels. Auxkernels store everything in the aux variable.
For material properties, we duplicate to duplicate the storage (element, neighbor, face)

Hi @GiudGiud ,
I have to create material properties using the  API of a external library (written in C++).  At the beginning of the simulation, I have to create a pointer to dynamically allocated API pointer. During the simulation, through the pointer, I can extract the necessary material properties. At the end of the simulation, I need to free the API pointer.
Can you tell me the appropriate place to allocate API pointer and to free the API pointer ? If I allocate it in the constructor, it looks like it will be called multiple times.
constructor and destructor seem fine, we just need to find a way to deactivate the creation of the face and neighbor copy. I ll have a look to see if that s possible

there's no option. Do you feel comfortable modifying FEProblemBase.C around line 3260 to make it happen?
also you must be confident that you dont need neighbor and face material, eg that you never have cases like looking at a face value

You could use FunctorMaterial.
It's a solid option, it will use on-the-fly evaluations of material properties.
There are brand new doc pages on functors:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Functors/index.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/FunctorMaterials/index.html

node.title: May 2023 Newsletter
node.bodyText:
The May 2023 MOOSE Newsletter has been released! A summary of the content is below:

Framework Improvements

New system: Positions
Possibility to combine TimeSteppers


Modules Improvements

Fluid properties for the NaK eutectic
Functor solid thermal properties
Dimensionality reduction in the stochastic tools module


Various bugfixes and enhancements (see descriptions)
Always ensure the mesh is prepared for use
Add capability to abort nonlinear/linear solves early using the Terminator
New objects: function average postprocessors
New documentation: Functor system
